This movie is very emotionally powerful.  A boy named "Pepper" who hormonally can't grow taller is somewhat of a social outcast, in WWII-era "O'Hare", California, a fictional coastal town (filmed in Tijuana and Baja).  He starts getting interested in magic shows and is guided by a Catholic priest played by Tom Wilkinson to channel his interest in the supernatural into a faith journey.  His dad has to go off to war, and Pepper struggles to know what it means to have faith in God, taking Jesus' statements literally about getting whatever you want if you have faith.  (Jesus' statements were probably specifically referring to spiritual gifts for ministering to others.)  The priest gives him a list which Pepper initially thinks is a checklist of all the good deeds he has to do to win God's favor, but which is actually the priest's way of trying to get him occupied on noble pursuits and less worried about his dad.  The hardest challenge for Pepper is learning to be genuinely kind to a Japanese man in the town, who is mostly a loner and initially views Pepper as an inconvenience.  The Japanese man does not believe in a Higher Power and is concerned the priest is just setting Pepper up for more disappointment by giving him a checklist to accomplish to please God.  However, all along, it's clear to someone watching the movie that the priest knows best, and that he's trying to develop character in Pepper so that Pepper will see there are more important things than getting God to give him a specific request.  When the Japanese man's safety is put in danger because of Pepper's older brother, who is fanatically anti-Jap like the American media was teaching people to be (in which sense the Americans were as wrong in their racial profiling as the Nazis were), the movie becomes very emotionally intense.  When the Japanese man is in danger, the movie starts taking you on a deeper journey of maturity with the characters.

The movie is structured like a series of episodes which incorporate abstract themes which we all wonder about:  1) Is righteousness just a list?  2) Is it just for the purpose of getting what I want from God?  3) Can I guarantee an outcome from God?  4) Should I INTERPRET every outcome (or even ANY outcome, for the Japanese agnostic character) as from God?  Its a movie in which you feel yourself grow up in the process of watching it.  It also is heartwarming even if the journey is sometimes heart-wrenching.  There is a lot of unpredictability about how things will turn out, and it feels painfully close to real life sometimes because of this uneasy combination of normal life with unexpected crises (which may be in the news or with personal relationships).  It's really an interesting exploration of how we view God and whether there are any guarantees in life.  Yet it also has entertainment value, not so much in a feel-good way but more like dramas such as Forrest Gump and War Horse, which affirm the value of life in the context of enduring losses and facing struggles.  This is a serious drama but one which left me uplifted rather than drained by the end.

The film centers around Pepper Flynt  Busbee (Jakob Salvati) growing up in O'Hare California during the war era. Pepper is short and gets the nickname "Little Boy" replacing "midget."  When his brother London (David Henrie) was rejected for service, dad (Michael Rapaport) who is Pepper's only friend, goes instead. When loyal Japanese are released from internment, Hashimoto (Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa) shows up in town befriended by a local priest (Tom Wilkinson). Dad is believed to be either dead or a POW in Japan. Pepper displays his disdain for "the Jap" in front of Father Oliver who tailors him a personal penance of good deeds. One of his deeds is to make friends with Hashimoto, the "face of the enemy."

As far as swearing and sex etc, the film is suitable for children. It deals with the harsh realities of prejudice and has off screen violence, i.e. it shows someone kicking a person, but not the actual kicks. Kevin James has a small role of Dr. Fox an ally of the family who has designs for Mrs. Busbee (Emily Watson). The film invokes emotions. It looks at faith vs the secular world and sees co-existence.

This was a sweet, heartwarming movie. It focuses on Pepper Busbee, a young boy growing up in O'Hare, California, during World War II. Pepper is small for his age and the bullies call him 'Little Boy.' He has no friends and relies on his father as his best friend. Unfortunately, his father goes off to war after Pepper's older brother, London, fails to qualify for service.

Pepper is desperate for his father's return. Upon advice from the local priest, he sets about performing performing a series of acts to prove his faith. He hopes God will reward him with a miracle. Among this acts is establishing a friendship with a Japanese man, Mr. Hashimoto.

There are some scenes in the movie that require the audience to suspend disbelief--such as one depicting a fortunately timed earthquake. It requires the same sort of acceptance by the audience as does Forrest Gump.

The movie is well-acted and well-produced. Jakob Salvati is adorable and lovable as little Pepper Busbee. There were some very sweet moments and some humorous ones as well. The movie gave me a sense of nostalgia for a time that came and went before I was born. There also were dark scenes, though, which showed the prejudices of the time and the cruelties that children can inflict upon one another.

Near the end of the movie came a scene I found horribly jarring and deeply unsettling. The film seemed to be making light of a tragic historical event and I found this incongruous, given the mature treatment of other subjects. Pepper's lack of compassion could be understood to be attributable to his young age, but I would have liked to have the adult Pepper address this in the narration, to provide a deeper context for what the film depicted. As it was, it seemed to betray all Pepper was supposed to have learned from befriending Hashimoto.

Aside from that one misstep, the film was very good.

Some critics call it misguided & "offensive." Of all things to be offended by in the world this is not one. I say grow up! Yes, there are negative attitudes/attributes in the film, but they are shown to be misguided, wrong-headed. They are also a part of history and we need to face history as it was, not as how we think it should have been. At its core, LITTLE BOY is extremely well-meaning and very sincere. It is also pleasantly devoid of exploitation, be it language or otherwise. Young Jakob Salvati gives a touching performance and the rest of the cast (which includes at least one Oscar winner in Tom Wilkinson) is solid as well. Alejandro Monteverde's direction is caring and affecting. I also found the score and most of the cinematography (save for some wartime footage that felt a little too crisp, to produced, if you will) well suited to the film.Little Boy

How did anyone like this movie?!  What on Earth is supposed to make me feel good about this supposedly "feel good" movie?  The priest can't just come out and say, "If you want your father back, the best thing you can do is get going praying your Rosary.  And be nice to the Japanese guy in town because that's the decent thing to do."  Instead he gives some completely non-understandable advice that leaves the boy trying some weird kind of magic to bring his father back, and no one ever corrects the child.  Not only do they not correct him, the boy ends up thinking that the magic really did accomplish something - something, I might add, that no child should ever want to be responsible for.

What is with the side story about the mother and the town doctor?  Creepy!  Emily Watson's strength is in playing the role of a strong, intelligent woman.  As another reviewer pointed out, her character was clueless in this film.  I found her character completely unlikable.  I was amazed that this movie had glowing reviews on IMDB.  I can't believe it is showing up as a five star movie on Amazon.  I'm one of those people who wants to support efforts to produce great family movies, but this movie isn't great.  It's horrible.

Little Boy is an extraordinary story of bravery, courage and the simple lesson of doing the right thing. Through many events, these key lessons are shown. The movie Little Boy takes place during World War Two on the coast of California. The main character, Pepper, is small for his age and often bullied and picked on because of it. His best and only friend is his father. But when the man he calls partner is drafted to fight for his country in the Philippines, Pepper has no one to protect him. With the war escalating, his brother, London, struggles to keep the family business afloat. With many family hardships, the last thing they need to hear is that James, Little Boys father, is missing in action. But when James does go MIA, as a POW, Pepper will do anything to bring him home.
Pepper, Jakob Salvati, is continuously bullied throughout the story, given the name Little Boy by the town for his height. His family gets worse everyday. His mother, played by Emily Watson, is always depressed. London, played by David Henrie, is an extremely unreliable brother to Pepper. London blames himself for his father going to war, he couldn't be drafted because of his flag feet, and resorts to alcohol to solve his problems. But, the story really kicks off when a Japanese - American, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, moves to the town.
 After being released from the camps, the whole town hates him, especially the families with loved ones in the war. London has extreme hatred for Hashimoto. Usually far from sober, London gets in plenty of trouble with the law for expressing his hatred. Soon enough, London winds up in jail. After the family of two loses the only man of the house, they become as troubled as ever.
Through this, Little Boy looks even father for hope. After hearing a sermon in church of moving a mountain with a mustard seed, hes determined to find these powers. The way to be more powerful is to increase your faith, the father tells him. Giving him a list of things to do to increase his faith, the very last one written is befriend Hashimoto. Believing that by doing this list he can bring his father back, Pepper accepts the challenge, willing to do anything to bring Dad back.
Through a very rocky start, Pepper apologizes to The Jap, an extremely courageous act on Peppers part. Only the priest will befriend him, but Pepper steps up to the plate because he knows it's right thing to do and it's what he has to do. Throughout spending time together, Hashimoto becomes Peppers friend, almost a father figure to him. Over the story, the older man gives many words of wisdom to Little Boy, giving him the strength to fight the bullies and overcome many problems. Through the story, Pepper achieves the respect he has longed for. Even when times become troubled, like when Hashimoto ends up in the hospital beaten half to death, or when his father is MIA, Pepper stays strong in his faith.
I really enjoyed this movie for many reasons. It's under the category of fiction/ fantasy, because of the powers, or actions of Pepper. But, the fictional act of Pepper moving a mountain and causing Little Boy are both linked through real events. Like how most things were based on real events, like the atomic bomb, the Japanese in camps, how the Americans treated the japanese, etc. These connections can help you relate to the story because they're historical events, which really backed up the story. Alejandro Gmez Monteverde, director and co- writer of Little Boy, is a fairly new and inexperienced director. There were a few flaws in the movie, or in the plot, that seemed to be lacking. For example, the story takes place in OHare, California, a fictional town that doesn't add to the plot. Also, Peppers age is never mentioned. I don't see a point to this, adding it would help the audience relate better.
What was really great about the movie was all of the lessons that were shown through Peppers many traits.  For example, befriending The Jap took a ton of courage and kindness, Pepper was hated by many for doing what he decided to do. Completing the many tasks that the priest asked of him, growing faith, gave us an image of how much love this Little Boy has for his father and how strong of a character this tiny boy is. He wasn't going to give up for anything. Watching Pepper transform from a bullied child to a boy with plenty of confidence, defeating bullies, was something I really enjoyed. It reveals many challenges that we can all connect to in real life. Pepper shows us how to get around many obstacles and how to face our problems. This movie is a 10/10 and I would recommend it to anyone.

Excellent slice-of-life period piece of 1940's World War Two era production. This story centers around the relationship between a little boy and the father he adores. Faith in a higher power are explored, and regardless of your personal beliefs, you can choose for yourself if events that occur are acts of God, consequences or just dumb luck. It is quite clear, however, which of these the "little boy" chooses to believe by the conclusion of the movie.  Kudos to the director for using restraint concerning the child actor; the child's "cute" factor was never once exploited, saving the film from becoming too sentimental and artificial.
